column4: this is a problem-- my period and comma keys don't respond anymore--  I can't use greater than or less than either-- I messed around a bit with the keyboard shortcuts in Ubuntu earlier-- attempting to assign period or comma to something gives a weird result-- imputting ctrl-period for the command displays ctrl-0xc3 and ctl-XF86AudioPlay-- --alternately
attempting to remap keyboard shortcuts via system-preferences-keyboard shortcuts
i would just wipe out ~/.gconf and maybe ~/.gnome2 and hope it fixes your mistake. you will lose any configuration you did
/gconf and /gnome are the shortcut maps? I presume?
~/.gconf and ~/.gnome2 are where all your gnome settings are stored
where can I find the gconf and gnome2 files?
also, if you switch to a VT your keyboard should be fine
typing ~/ brings me to my home folder-- I don't see gconf or gnome2----  argh
they are hidden, hidden files start with a .
ahh I see-- It hadn't even occurred to me that ubuntu would hide system files
it is not system files, it is any file that starts with a .  this is a very old unix thing :-)
if you use the -a option in ls you can see them
you can toggle seeing hidden files in nautilus with ctrl-h, iirc
